questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is an example of an application using Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)?
question_texts: Which of the following is an example of an application using Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)?

options.option_text: A system where users are granted access based on their job roles within anorganization.
A cloud service that grants or restricts access to files based on attributes suchas user department, job title, or current location.
A file-sharing system where the file owner decides who can access theirdocuments.
A system that enforces access based on security classifications and clearancelevels.

options.option_text: The Constraint Validation API ensures that form input meets client-sidevalidation rules before submission.
The Constraint Validation API is sufficient to prevent server-side attacks likeSQL injection.
It is possible to bypass the Constraint Validation API by directly sendingrequests to the server.
The Constraint Validation API automatically validates all data on the serverside.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the core topics, concepts, and principles essential for the **Diploma Level: Modern Application Development I** exam, along with a knowledge graph in Mermaid syntax. --- ## **Core Topics and Concepts Summary** ### **1. Web Development with Flask** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Flask Basics**: Routing, request handling, templates (Jinja2), and context management. - **Request Methods**: `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, etc. - **URL Handling**: Dynamic routing (`/`), query parameters (`?key=value`). - **Templates (Jinja2)**: - Template inheritance (`{% extends %}`, `{% block %}`). - Variable substitution (`{{ variable }}`). - Conditional rendering (`{% if %}`). - **Error Handling**: Custom error pages (`@app.errorhandler`). - **Logging**: Configuring logs (`logging.basicConfig`), log levels (`debug`, `info`, `warning`). - **Flask-RESTful**: Building REST APIs with resources and request parsing. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # Basic Flask App from flask import Flask app = Flask(__name__) @app.route('/') def home(): return "Hello, World!" app.run(debug=True) # Dynamic Routing @app.route('/user/') def show_user(username): return f"User: {username}" # Query Parameters from flask import request @app.route('/search') def search(): query = request.args.get('q') return f"Search query: {query}" # Jinja2 Template Rendering from flask import render_template @app.route('/template') def template(): return render_template('index.html', title="Home") # REST API with Flask-RESTful from flask_restful import Api, Resource api = Api(app) class HelloWorld(Resource): def get(self): return {"message": "Hello, World!"} api.add_resource(HelloWorld, '/api/hello') ``` #### **Equations (Math-Related):** - **Bandwidth Decay (Q8)**: \[ B(t) = B_0 \times \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^t \] where \( B_0 \) = initial bandwidth, \( t \) = time in hours. - **Data Consumption (Q8)**: \[ \text{Total Data (GB)} = \sum_{t=0}^{n-1} \left( B(t) \times \text{time} \times \frac{1}{8 \times 1024} \right) \] - **Character Encoding (Q26)**: \[ \text{Min bits per character} = \lceil \log_2(n) \rceil \] where \( n \) = number of unique characters. --- ### **2. Databases and SQLAlchemy** #### **Key Concepts:** - **SQLAlchemy Models**: Defining tables, relationships (`ForeignKey`), and constraints. - **Relationships**: - One-to-Many: Foreign key in the "many" table (e.g., `Book.library_id` references `Library.id`). - Many-to-Many: Requires an association table. - **Time-Series Databases**: InfluxDB (vs. MongoDB, MySQL, PostgreSQL). - **Primary Keys**: Unique, non-null, can be auto-incremented. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # SQLAlchemy One-to-Many Relationship class Library(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) books = db.relationship('Book', backref='library') class Book(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) library_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('library.id')) # Querying with SQLAlchemy books = Book.query.filter_by(library_id=1).all() ``` --- ### **3. Frontend Development (HTML/CSS/JS)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **DOM (Document Object Model)**: Structure of HTML documents, nodes, and events. - **HTML Lists**: Ordered (`
    `), unordered (`
      `), and nested lists. - **CSS Specificity**: Inline styles vs. IDs vs. classes. - **JavaScript DOM Manipulation**: - Selecting elements (`getElementById`, `querySelector`). - Modifying styles (`element.style.property`). - **Constraint Validation API**: Client-side form validation (e.g., `required`, `pattern`). #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```html
      1. Item 1
        • Subitem 1
      ``` --- ### **4. Testing and Debugging** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Unit Testing with `pytest`**: - Assertions (`assert`). - Fixtures (`@pytest.fixture`). - Running tests (`pytest file.py`). - **Flask Test Context**: Simulating requests (`app.test_request_context`). - **Error Handling**: Custom exceptions, HTTP error codes (404, 403). #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # Pytest Example def test_addition(): assert 1 + 1 == 2 # Flask Test Context with app.test_request_context('/user?name=John'): print(request.args['name']) # Output: John # Custom Error Handling from werkzeug.exceptions import HTTPException class MyError(HTTPException): def __init__(self, message): super().__init__(message, 400) ``` --- ### **5. Data Structures and Algorithms** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Factorials and Recursion**: Calculating factorials (`math.factorial`). - **Decorators**: Wrapping functions for pre/post-processing. - **Data Encoding**: Calculating minimum bits for character sets. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # Decorator Example def prettify(func): def wrapper(*args, **kwargs): try: return func(*args, **kwargs) except: return "Error occurred!" return wrapper @prettify def divide(a, b): return a / b ``` --- ### **6. Access Control Models** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)**: Access based on attributes (e.g., role, department). - **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**: Access based on user roles. --- ### **7. Networking and Bandwidth** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Bandwidth vs. Throughput**: Bandwidth (max capacity), throughput (actual data transfer). - **Data Conversion**: - 1 Byte = 8 bits. - 1 KB = 1000 Bytes, 1 MB = 1000 KB. #### **Equations:** - **Network Speed (Q27)**: \[ \text{Max Requests/sec} = \frac{\text{Network Speed (KBps)}}{\text{Request Size (KB)}} \] --- ### **8. REST APIs and HTTP Methods** #### **Key Concepts:** - **HTTP Methods**: - `GET`: Retrieve data. - `POST`: Create data. - `PUT`: Update data. - `DELETE`: Delete data. - **Request Parsing**: Handling JSON payloads (`request.get_json`). - **Status Codes**: - 200: OK. - 201: Created. - 400: Bad Request. - 404: Not Found. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # Flask-RESTful PUT Request class Item(Resource): def put(self, id): data = request.get_json() items[id] = data return items[id], 201 ``` --- ## **Knowledge Graph (Mermaid Syntax)** ### **Graph 1: Flask and Web Development** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask] --> B[Routing] A --> C[Templates Jinja2] A --> D[Request Handling] A --> E[Error Handling] A --> F[REST APIs] B --> G[Dynamic Routes /] B --> H[Query Parameters ?key=value] C --> I[Template Inheritance] C --> J[Variable Substitution] D --> K[GET/POST/PUT] D --> L[Request Parsing] F --> M[Flask-RESTful] F --> N[HTTP Methods] ``` ### **Graph 2: Databases and SQLAlchemy** ```mermaid graph TD A[Databases] --> B[SQLAlchemy] A --> C[Time-Series DBs] B --> D[Models] B --> E[Relationships] E --> F[One-to-Many] E --> G[Many-to-Many] C --> H[InfluxDB] C --> I[MongoDB] C --> J[PostgreSQL] ``` ### **Graph 3: Frontend Development** ```mermaid graph TD A[Frontend] --> B[HTML] A --> C[CSS] A --> D[JavaScript] B --> E[Lists ol/ul] B --> F[DOM Structure] C --> G[Specificity] C --> H[Inline vs Classes] D --> I[DOM Manipulation] D --> J[Event Handling] F --> K[Nodes] F --> L[Events] ``` ### **Graph 4: Testing and Debugging** ```mermaid graph TD A[Testing] --> B[Unit Testing] A --> C[Flask Testing] B --> D[pytest] B --> E[Fixtures] B --> F[Assertions] C --> G[test_request_context] C --> H[Error Simulation] ``` ### **Graph 5: Data and Networking** ```mermaid graph TD A[Data] --> B[Encoding] A --> C[Bandwidth] B --> D[Character Sets] B --> E[Min Bits Calculation] C --> F[Decay Over Time] C --> G[Data Conversion] G --> H[Bits to Bytes] G --> I[KB to MB] ```
